docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Welcome to the study of trigonometric functions! Before we dive into trigonometry, we need to establish a solid foundation in geometry. This chapter reviews essential geometric concepts that form the building blocks for understanding trigonometric ratios.

Geometry provides the visual and logical framework for trigonometry. When you understand triangles—their properties, angles, and relationships—you'll be well-prepared to explore how trigonometric functions connect angles to side lengths.

docs.title: Chapter Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After completing this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Remember: Recall definitions of different triangle types and angle types
  • Understand: Explain the properties of triangles and angle relationships
  • Apply: Use angle properties to solve geometric problems
  • Analyze: Compare different triangle classifications and identify key features

docs.title: What is a Triangle?
docs.text:
A triangle is a polygon with three sides, three angles, and three vertices (corner points). Triangles are among the most fundamental shapes in geometry and serve as the foundation for trigonometry.

Key Components of a Triangle: - Sides: The three line segments that form the triangle's boundary - Angles: The three angles formed where sides meet - Vertices: The three points where sides intersect

Important Property: The sum of all three angles in any triangle equals 180 degrees.

docs.title: Types of Triangles
docs.text: Triangles are classified in two main ways: by their sides and by their angles.

docs.title: Classification by Sides
docs.text:
Equilateral Triangle - All three sides have equal length - All three angles are equal (each measures 60°) - Perfectly balanced and symmetrical

Isosceles Triangle - Two sides have equal length - Two angles are equal (the angles opposite the equal sides) - Has a line of symmetry

Scalene Triangle - All three sides have different lengths - All three angles are different sizes - Asymmetrical shape

docs.title: Classification by Angles
docs.text:
Acute Triangle - All three angles are less than 90° - Sometimes called "sharp" triangles - Often appears pointed or well-balanced

Right Triangle - One angle is exactly 90° (a right angle, shown with a small square) - The other two angles are acute (less than 90°) - Sides have special relationships (Pythagorean theorem) - Most important for trigonometry!

Obtuse Triangle - One angle is greater than 90° (obtuse) - The other two angles are acute - Often appears "flat" or spread out

Run Angle Explorer Fullscreen

docs.title: Important Geometric Properties
docs.text:
Angle Sum Property: The sum of all three interior angles in any triangle is always 180°.

If a triangle has angles A, B, and C, then: \(\(A + B + C = 180°\)\)

Exterior Angle Property: An exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.

Vertex Relationships: Understanding how angles and sides relate at vertices is crucial for later work with trigonometric ratios.

docs.title: Example 1.1: Identifying Triangle Types
docs.text:
Problem: Classify each triangle: 1. A triangle with sides 5 cm, 5 cm, and 7 cm 2. A triangle with angles 45°, 45°, and 90° 3. A triangle with angles 30°, 60°, and 90°

Solution:

  1. First triangle (5 cm, 5 cm, 7 cm)
  2. Two sides are equal (5 cm each)
  3. Classification by sides: Isosceles triangle

  4. To classify by angles, we'd need to calculate them using more advanced methods

  5. Second triangle (45°, 45°, 90°)

  6. One angle is exactly 90°
  7. Classification by angles: Right triangle
  8. The two equal 45° angles suggest this is also isosceles (since equal angles opposite equal sides)

  9. Full classification: Isosceles right triangle

  10. Third triangle (30°, 60°, 90°)

  11. One angle is exactly 90°
  12. Classification by angles: Right triangle
  13. This is a special right triangle (30-60-90)
  14. All three sides have different lengths
  15. Full classification: Scalene right triangle

docs.title: Example 1.2: Using the Angle Sum Property
docs.text:
Problem: In a triangle, one angle measures 50°, another measures 65°. What is the measure of the third angle?

Solution:

Using the angle sum property: \(\(A + B + C = 180°\)\)

Substituting known values: \(\(50° + 65° + C = 180°\)\)

\[115° + C = 180°\] \[C = 180° - 115°\] \[C = 65°\]

Answer: The third angle measures 65°.

Note: Since two angles are equal (65° each), this is an isosceles triangle.

docs.title: Example 1.3: Finding an Exterior Angle
docs.text:
Problem: A triangle has interior angles of 40°, 70°, and 70°. If you extend one of the sides forming the 40° angle, what is the measure of the exterior angle formed?

Solution:

Using the exterior angle property: An exterior angle equals the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.

The two non-adjacent angles (the ones not at the vertex where the exterior angle is formed) are 70° and 70°.

Exterior angle = 70° + 70° = 140°

Verification: The exterior angle and its adjacent interior angle should sum to 180°: - 140° + 40° = 180° ✓

docs.title: What is an Angle?
docs.text:
An angle is formed by two rays that share a common endpoint (called the vertex). Angles measure the amount of rotation from one ray to the other, typically measured in degrees.

Angle Notation: An angle can be labeled with three letters (with the vertex in the middle) or with a single letter or number representing the vertex.

docs.title: Angle Types
docs.text:
Acute Angle - Measures less than 90° - Sharp or pointed appearance - Examples: 30°, 45°, 60°, 80°

Right Angle - Measures exactly 90° - Shown with a small square symbol in diagrams - Created when two perpendicular lines meet - Example: Corners of a square or rectangle

Obtuse Angle - Measures greater than 90° but less than 180° - Wide or spread-out appearance - Examples: 100°, 120°, 150°

Straight Angle - Measures exactly 180° - Forms a straight line - Actually two rays pointing in opposite directions

docs.title: Angle Relationships
docs.text:
Complementary Angles - Two angles that sum to exactly 90° - Example: 30° and 60° are complementary - In a right triangle, the two acute angles are always complementary - If one angle is x°, its complement is (90 - x)°

Supplementary Angles - Two angles that sum to exactly 180° - Example: 120° and 60° are supplementary - Often found on a straight line - If one angle is x°, its supplement is (180 - x)°

Vertical Angles - Angles opposite each other when two lines intersect - Vertical angles are always equal - Important for understanding geometry diagrams

Adjacent Angles - Angles that share a common vertex and a common side - Found frequently in geometric figures - May or may not be equal

docs.title: Angle Measurement
docs.text:
Degrees: The most common unit for measuring angles in basic trigonometry - One complete rotation = 360° - A right angle = 90° - Degrees can be subdivided into minutes (') and seconds (") - 1° = 60 minutes, 1 minute = 60 seconds

Radians: An alternative unit used especially in advanced mathematics - One complete rotation = 2π radians - A right angle = π/2 radians - We'll use degrees primarily in this course, with brief introduction to radians

docs.title: Interior and Exterior Angles
docs.text:
Interior Angles: The angles inside a triangle (the ones we usually focus on)

Exterior Angles: Angles formed by extending one side of a triangle beyond a vertex - An exterior angle and its adjacent interior angle are supplementary (sum to 180°) - An exterior angle equals the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles

docs.title: Example 1.4: Working with Complementary Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Two complementary angles have measures where one angle is 20° more than the other. Find both angles.

Solution:

Let x = the smaller angle Then x + 20 = the larger angle

Since they're complementary, they sum to 90°: \(\(x + (x + 20) = 90°\)\)

\[2x + 20 = 90°\] \[2x = 70°\] \[x = 35°\]

Answer: - Smaller angle: 35° - Larger angle: 55°

Verification: 35° + 55° = 90° ✓

docs.title: Example 1.5: Identifying Supplementary Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Two supplementary angles have a ratio of 2:3. Find both angles.

Solution:

Let 2x = the smaller angle Let 3x = the larger angle

Since they're supplementary, they sum to 180°: \(\(2x + 3x = 180°\)\)

\[5x = 180°\] \[x = 36°\]

Answer: - Smaller angle: 2(36°) = 72° - Larger angle: 3(36°) = 108°

Verification: 72° + 108° = 180° ✓

docs.title: Example 1.6: Using Vertical Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Two lines intersect forming four angles. One angle measures 65°. What are the measures of the other three angles?

Solution:

When two lines intersect, they form two pairs of vertical angles: - Vertical angles are equal - Adjacent angles are supplementary (sum to 180°)

If one angle is 65°: - Its vertical angle = 65° (vertical angles equal) - Each adjacent angle = 180° - 65° = 115° - The angle vertical to one of the 115° angles = 115°

Answer: The four angles are 65°, 115°, 65°, and 115°

docs.text:

docs.title: Key Concepts Reviewed
docs.text:
Triangle Classification - By sides: Equilateral, Isosceles, Scalene - By angles: Acute, Right, Obtuse - A triangle can be classified both ways

Important Triangle Property - Sum of interior angles = 180°

Angle Types and Relationships - Complementary angles sum to 90° - Supplementary angles sum to 180° - Vertical angles are equal - Adjacent angles share a vertex and side

Exterior Angles - Exterior angle = sum of two non-adjacent interior angles - Exterior angle + adjacent interior angle = 180°

docs.title: Why This Matters for Trigonometry
docs.text:

  1. Right triangles are central to trigonometry - We'll use the properties of right triangles throughout this course

  3. Vocabulary and concepts are referenced constantly - Terms like "adjacent side," "opposite side," and "vertex" appear throughout trigonometry

  4. Geometric visualization supports understanding - Many trigonometric concepts are easier to understand when you can visualize the geometric relationships

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most important relationships in mathematics. It describes a fundamental property of right triangles that has been used for thousands of years—from ancient Egypt to modern engineering. This theorem not only connects the sides of a right triangle but also forms the foundation for trigonometric ratios and many real-world applications.

In this chapter, we'll explore the theorem itself, understand why it works, and learn how to apply it to solve problems. By mastering the Pythagorean theorem, you're building essential skills for trigonometry.

docs.title: Chapter Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After completing this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Remember: Recall the Pythagorean theorem statement and recognize Pythagorean triples
  • Understand: Explain why the Pythagorean theorem works and identify its components
  • Apply: Use the theorem to find missing sides and verify right triangles
  • Analyze: Compare different methods for solving right triangle problems

docs.title: The Pythagorean Theorem Statement
docs.text:
In a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse (the longest side, opposite the right angle) equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

Mathematical Formula: \(\(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\)\)

Where: - a and b are the lengths of the two legs (the sides that form the right angle) - c is the length of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle)

docs.title: Understanding the Components
docs.text:
The Hypotenuse - The longest side of a right triangle - Always opposite the right angle - The side that "closes" the triangle across from the right angle

The Legs - The two sides that form the right angle - Always shorter than the hypotenuse - Called the "legs" because they form the corner

docs.title: Why It Works: Visual Proof
docs.text:
The Pythagorean theorem can be proven geometrically. If you draw squares on each side of a right triangle, the area of the square on the hypotenuse equals the sum of the areas of the squares on the two legs.

Area relationships: - Square on leg a: area = a² - Square on leg b: area = b² - Square on hypotenuse c: area = c² - Therefore: a² + b² = c²

docs.title: The Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem
docs.text:
The converse (reverse) of the theorem is also true:

If the square of one side of a triangle equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides, then the triangle is a right triangle.

Mathematically: If a² + b² = c², then the triangle is a right triangle.

This is useful for verifying whether a triangle is a right triangle when you know all three side lengths.

docs.title: Pythagorean Triples
docs.text:
A Pythagorean triple is a set of three positive whole numbers that satisfy the Pythagorean theorem.

Common Pythagorean Triples: - (3, 4, 5) → 3² + 4² = 9 + 16 = 25 = 5² - (5, 12, 13) → 5² + 12² = 25 + 144 = 169 = 13² - (8, 15, 17) → 8² + 15² = 64 + 225 = 289 = 17² - (7, 24, 25) → 7² + 24² = 49 + 576 = 625 = 25²

Multiples of Pythagorean Triples are also Pythagorean triples: - (6, 8, 10) is 2 × (3, 4, 5) - (9, 12, 15) is 3 × (3, 4, 5)

Why These Matter: - Easy to recognize and work with - Often appear in textbooks because they involve whole numbers - Help develop intuition about right triangles

docs.title: Example 2.1: Finding a Missing Leg
docs.text:
Problem: A right triangle has one leg of length 3 cm and a hypotenuse of length 5 cm. Find the length of the other leg.

Solution:

Using the Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c²

Let a = 3 cm (known leg), b = unknown leg, c = 5 cm (hypotenuse)

\[3^2 + b^2 = 5^2\] \[9 + b^2 = 25\] \[b^2 = 25 - 9\] \[b^2 = 16\] \[b = \sqrt{16} = 4 \text{ cm}\]

Answer: The other leg is 4 cm.

Check: 3² + 4² = 9 + 16 = 25 = 5² ✓ (This is the famous 3-4-5 Pythagorean triple!)

docs.title: Example 2.2: Finding the Hypotenuse
docs.text:
Problem: A right triangle has legs of length 5 m and 12 m. Find the length of the hypotenuse.

Solution:

Using the Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c²

Let a = 5 m, b = 12 m, c = hypotenuse (unknown)

\[5^2 + 12^2 = c^2\] \[25 + 144 = c^2\] \[169 = c^2\] \[c = \sqrt{169} = 13 \text{ m}\]

Answer: The hypotenuse is 13 m.

Check: This is the 5-12-13 Pythagorean triple! ✓

docs.title: Example 2.3: Verifying a Right Triangle
docs.text:
Problem: Is a triangle with sides 6 cm, 8 cm, and 10 cm a right triangle?

Solution:

To verify, check if the Pythagorean theorem holds. The longest side (10 cm) should be the hypotenuse.

\[6^2 + 8^2 = 36 + 64 = 100\] \[10^2 = 100\]

Since 6² + 8² = 10², the equation holds true.

Answer: Yes, this is a right triangle.

Note: (6, 8, 10) is the 3-4-5 triple multiplied by 2.

docs.title: Using the Theorem in Real Situations
docs.text: The Pythagorean theorem appears everywhere: - Construction: Ensuring walls are perpendicular (square corners) - Navigation: Calculating distances between points - Engineering: Designing structures with specific angles - Ladder placement: Finding safe distances from walls

docs.title: Distance Formula Connection
docs.text:
The distance between two points in a coordinate plane can be found using the Pythagorean theorem. If two points are at (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂):

\[d = \sqrt{(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2}\]

This is the Pythagorean theorem applied to a coordinate system!

docs.title: Multi-Step Problems
docs.text: Many real-world problems require multiple applications of the Pythagorean theorem or combining it with other geometric concepts.

docs.title: Example 2.4: Application - Ladder Problem
docs.text:
Problem: A 10-meter ladder is placed against a wall. The base of the ladder is 6 meters from the wall. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?

Solution:

Visualize this as a right triangle: - Hypotenuse (ladder) = 10 m - One leg (distance from wall) = 6 m - Other leg (height on wall) = unknown (h)

Using the Pythagorean theorem: \(\(6^2 + h^2 = 10^2\)\)

\[36 + h^2 = 100\] \[h^2 = 64\] \[h = 8 \text{ meters}\]

Answer: The ladder reaches 8 meters up the wall.

docs.title: Example 2.5: Application - Distance Between Points
docs.text:
Problem: Find the distance between points A(0, 0) and B(3, 4) on a coordinate plane.

Solution:

Using the distance formula (which is the Pythagorean theorem): \(\(d = \sqrt{(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2}\)\)

\[d = \sqrt{(3-0)^2 + (4-0)^2}\] \[d = \sqrt{9 + 16}\] \[d = \sqrt{25} = 5\]

Answer: The distance is 5 units.

docs.title: Example 2.6: Comparing Sides Using the Theorem
docs.text:
Problem: In a right triangle, is side a larger or smaller than side b if: - Leg a = 7 inches - Leg b = ? inches - Hypotenuse c = 15 inches

Solution:

\[a^2 + b^2 = c^2\] \[7^2 + b^2 = 15^2\] \[49 + b^2 = 225\] \[b^2 = 176\] \[b = \sqrt{176} \approx 13.27 \text{ inches}\]

Answer: Since 13.27 > 7, side b is larger than side a.

docs.title: When to Use the Pythagorean Theorem
docs.text: Use the theorem when: - You know two sides of a right triangle and need the third - You need to verify if a triangle is a right triangle - You're finding distances in geometry or on a coordinate plane - You're working with real-world problems involving perpendicular relationships

docs.title: Why This Matters for Trigonometry
docs.text:
The Pythagorean theorem is absolutely essential for trigonometry because:

  1. It defines right triangles - Trigonometric ratios only apply to right triangles
  2. It connects sides and angles - The relationship between sides is foundational to understanding sine, cosine, and tangent
  3. It's used in verifying calculations - You can check trigonometric calculations using the Pythagorean theorem
  4. It appears throughout applications - Many real-world problems use both the theorem and trigonometric ratios

docs.title: Looking Ahead
docs.text: In Chapter 3, we'll introduce trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent), which connect the angles of a right triangle to the relationships between its sides. Understanding the Pythagorean theorem makes learning these ratios much easier!

docs.title: Chapter 3: Trigonometric Ratios in Right Triangles
Introduction
docs.text:
Now that you understand the foundations of geometry and the Pythagorean theorem, we're ready to explore the heart of trigonometry: trigonometric ratios. These ratios connect the angles of a right triangle to the relationships between its sides, allowing us to solve problems involving distances, heights, and angles that would be difficult or impossible to measure directly.

Trigonometry literally means "triangle measurement," and the trigonometric ratios—sine, cosine, and tangent—are the fundamental tools that make this measurement possible. Ancient astronomers, navigators, and surveyors used these ratios to measure the heavens, chart the seas, and map the land. Today, they're essential in fields from architecture to video game design.

docs.title: Chapter Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After completing this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Remember: Recall the definitions of sine, cosine, tangent, and their reciprocal functions
  • Understand: Explain the SOHCAHTOA mnemonic and identify triangle components
  • Apply: Calculate trigonometric ratios for given right triangles
  • Analyze: Determine which trigonometric ratio to use for different problems
  • Evaluate: Verify solutions using multiple approaches

docs.title: What Are Trigonometric Ratios?
docs.text:
A trigonometric ratio compares two sides of a right triangle. The value of the ratio depends on the size of one of the acute angles in the triangle.

Key Insight: For a given angle measure, the ratio between certain sides of a right triangle is always the same, regardless of the triangle's size. This consistent relationship is what makes trigonometry so powerful.

docs.title: Labeling Right Triangle Components
docs.text:
Before we can work with trigonometric ratios, we need to understand how to label a right triangle relative to a specific angle.

The Three Sides (relative to an acute angle θ):

  1. Hypotenuse - The longest side, always opposite the right angle
  2. Opposite side - The side across from the angle θ
  3. Adjacent side - The side next to the angle θ (not the hypotenuse)

Important: The "opposite" and "adjacent" sides change depending on which angle you're considering! The hypotenuse never changes.

docs.title: The Three Primary Trigonometric Ratios
docs.text:
Sine (sin) \(\(\sin \theta = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}}\)\)

Cosine (cos) \(\(\cos \theta = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}}\)\)

Tangent (tan) \(\(\tan \theta = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}}\)\)

Where θ (theta) represents the angle we're working with.

docs.title: Understanding the Ratios
docs.text:
Sine tells us how "tall" the triangle is relative to its hypotenuse. It compares the vertical height to the longest side.

Cosine tells us how "wide" the triangle is relative to its hypotenuse. It compares the horizontal distance to the longest side.

Tangent tells us the "steepness" or slope of the triangle. It compares height to horizontal distance.

docs.title: Why These Ratios Are Constant
docs.text:
If you create two right triangles with the same acute angle but different sizes, the triangles are similar (same shape, different size). Similar triangles have proportional sides, so the ratios remain constant.

This is why a 30° angle always has the same sine value (0.5), regardless of how large the triangle is!

docs.title: Example 3.1: Identifying Triangle Components
docs.text:
Problem: In right triangle ABC with right angle at C, identify the opposite side, adjacent side, and hypotenuse relative to angle A if: - Side AB (connecting A to B) = 13 cm - Side AC (connecting A to C) = 5 cm - Side BC (connecting B to C) = 12 cm

Solution:

First, identify the right angle: at C

Relative to angle A: - Hypotenuse: AB = 13 cm (opposite the right angle, longest side) - Opposite side: BC = 12 cm (across from angle A) - Adjacent side: AC = 5 cm (next to angle A, forming the angle)

Verification: Check using Pythagorean theorem: 5² + 12² = 25 + 144 = 169 = 13² ✓

docs.title: Example 3.2: Calculating Basic Trigonometric Ratios
docs.text:
Problem: Using the triangle from Example 3.1, find sin A, cos A, and tan A.

Solution:

From Example 3.1: - Opposite = 12 cm - Adjacent = 5 cm - Hypotenuse = 13 cm

\[\sin A = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{12}{13}\] \[\cos A = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{5}{13}\] \[\tan A = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}} = \frac{12}{5}\]

Answer: - sin A = 12/13 ≈ 0.923 - cos A = 5/13 ≈ 0.385 - tan A = 12/5 = 2.4

docs.title: Example 3.3: Finding Ratios for the Other Angle
docs.text:
Problem: Using the same triangle, find sin B, cos B, and tan B.

Solution:

Now we're working with angle B. The labels change: - Hypotenuse: still AB = 13 cm (never changes) - Opposite (to angle B): AC = 5 cm - Adjacent (to angle B): BC = 12 cm

\[\sin B = \frac{5}{13}\] \[\cos B = \frac{12}{13}\] \[\tan B = \frac{5}{12}\]

Important observation: Notice that sin A = cos B and cos A = sin B. This is because angles A and B are complementary (they sum to 90°)!

docs.title: Example 3.4: Using the 3-4-5 Triangle
docs.text:
Problem: Find all six trigonometric ratios (including reciprocals) for the 30° angle in a 3-4-5 right triangle where the side opposite the angle is 3 units.

Solution:

In this triangle: - Opposite = 3 - Adjacent = 4 - Hypotenuse = 5

Primary ratios: \(\(\sin \theta = \frac{3}{5} = 0.6\)\)

\[\cos \theta = \frac{4}{5} = 0.8\] \[\tan \theta = \frac{3}{4} = 0.75\]

Reciprocal ratios (covered in next section): \(\(\csc \theta = \frac{5}{3} \approx 1.667\)\)

\[\sec \theta = \frac{5}{4} = 1.25\] \[\cot \theta = \frac{4}{3} \approx 1.333\]

docs.title: Section 3.2: Right Triangle Components and SOHCAHTOA
The SOHCAHTOA Mnemonic
docs.text:
SOHCAHTOA is a memory device to help you remember the three primary trigonometric ratios:

  • SOH: Sine = Opposite / Hypotenuse
  • CAH: Cosine = Adjacent / Hypotenuse
  • TOA: Tangent = Opposite / Adjacent

Many students find this easier to remember by creating a sentence: "Some Old Hippie Caught Another Hippie Tripping On Acid" (or any other memorable phrase you prefer!).

docs.title: Reciprocal Trigonometric Functions
docs.text:
In addition to sine, cosine, and tangent, there are three reciprocal functions:

Cosecant (csc) - reciprocal of sine \(\(\csc \theta = \frac{1}{\sin \theta} = \frac{\text{hypotenuse}}{\text{opposite}}\)\)

Secant (sec) - reciprocal of cosine \(\(\sec \theta = \frac{1}{\cos \theta} = \frac{\text{hypotenuse}}{\text{adjacent}}\)\)

Cotangent (cot) - reciprocal of tangent \(\(\cot \theta = \frac{1}{\tan \theta} = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{opposite}}\)\)

docs.title: When to Use Each Ratio
docs.text:
The key to selecting the right trigonometric ratio is identifying which sides you know and which you need to find:

Use sine when working with: - Opposite side and hypotenuse - Problems involving vertical heights

Use cosine when working with: - Adjacent side and hypotenuse - Problems involving horizontal distances

Use tangent when working with: - Opposite and adjacent sides (no hypotenuse) - Slope or steepness problems

docs.title: Complementary Angle Relationships
docs.text:
In a right triangle, the two acute angles are complementary (sum to 90°). This creates special relationships:

Cofunction identities: - sin θ = cos(90° - θ) - cos θ = sin(90° - θ) - tan θ = cot(90° - θ)

This is why the sine of one acute angle equals the cosine of the other acute angle!

docs.title: Example 3.5: Applying SOHCAHTOA
docs.text:
Problem: A right triangle has a hypotenuse of 20 meters and one angle of 40°. The side opposite this angle is x meters. Which trigonometric ratio should you use, and what equation would you set up?

Solution:

Given: - Hypotenuse = 20 m - Angle = 40° - Opposite = x (unknown)

Analysis: We have the hypotenuse and need the opposite side. Using SOHCAHTOA: - SOH: Sine = Opposite / Hypotenuse ✓ (This matches our known and unknown!)

Equation: \(\(\sin 40° = \frac{x}{20}\)\)

Solving: \(\(x = 20 \sin 40°\)\) \(\(x = 20(0.643) \approx 12.86 \text{ meters}\)\)

Answer: The opposite side is approximately 12.86 meters.

docs.title: Example 3.6: Using Reciprocal Functions
docs.text:
Problem: If sin θ = 5/13, find csc θ without using a calculator.

Solution:

By definition, cosecant is the reciprocal of sine:

\[\csc \theta = \frac{1}{\sin \theta}\] \[\csc \theta = \frac{1}{5/13} = \frac{13}{5}\]

Answer: csc θ = 13/5 = 2.6

Note: You can also think of this as "flip the fraction."

docs.title: Example 3.7: Finding All Ratios from One
docs.text:
Problem: If cos A = 4/5 in a right triangle, find all other trigonometric ratios for angle A.

Solution:

Given: cos A = 4/5, which means adjacent = 4 and hypotenuse = 5

Step 1: Find the opposite side using Pythagorean theorem: \(\(a^2 + 4^2 = 5^2\)\) \(\(a^2 + 16 = 25\)\) \(\(a^2 = 9\)\) \(\(a = 3\)\)

Step 2: Calculate all ratios: - sin A = 3/5 = 0.6 - cos A = 4/5 = 0.8 (given) - tan A = 3/4 = 0.75 - csc A = 5/3 ≈ 1.667 - sec A = 5/4 = 1.25 - cot A = 4/3 ≈ 1.333

Verification: Check that reciprocals multiply to 1: - (3/5)(5/3) = 1 ✓ - (4/5)(5/4) = 1 ✓ - (3/4)(4/3) = 1 ✓

docs.title: Example 3.8: Using Cofunction Identities
docs.text:
Problem: If sin 28° = 0.469, what is cos 62°? Explain your reasoning.

Solution:

Notice that 28° + 62° = 90°, so these angles are complementary.

Using the cofunction identity: \(\(\sin \theta = \cos(90° - \theta)\)\)

\[\sin 28° = \cos(90° - 28°) = \cos 62°\]

Answer: cos 62° = 0.469

Explanation: In a right triangle, the two acute angles are complementary. The sine of one angle equals the cosine of its complement because the "opposite" side for one angle is the "adjacent" side for the other angle.

docs.title: Finding Unknown Sides
docs.text:
When you know one side and one acute angle of a right triangle, you can find any other side using trigonometric ratios.

General Strategy: 1. Draw and label the triangle 2. Identify the given angle and what you know/need 3. Choose the appropriate ratio (SOHCAHTOA) 4. Set up the equation 5. Solve for the unknown 6. Check reasonableness

docs.title: Finding Unknown Angles
docs.text:
If you know all three sides of a right triangle, you can find the acute angles using inverse trigonometric functions (which we'll study in detail in Chapter 7).

For now, you can verify angle calculations by checking that all three angles sum to 180°.

docs.title: Real-World Problem Types
docs.text: Height problems: Finding the height of buildings, trees, or mountains Distance problems: Finding horizontal distances that can't be measured directly Angle of elevation: Angle above horizontal Angle of depression: Angle below horizontal

docs.title: Problem-Solving Tips
docs.text:
1. Always draw a diagram - Label all known information
  2. Check which angle you're working with - Opposite and adjacent depend on this
  3. Use consistent units - Convert if necessary
  4. Verify your answer - Does it make sense? Is it reasonable?
  5. Use Pythagorean theorem to check - All three sides should satisfy a² + b² = c²

docs.title: Example 3.9: Finding a Missing Side (Opposite)
docs.text:
Problem: A 15-foot ladder leans against a wall, making a 70° angle with the ground. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?

Solution:

Draw and label: - Hypotenuse (ladder) = 15 ft - Angle with ground = 70° - Opposite (height up wall) = h (unknown)

Choose ratio: We have hypotenuse, need opposite → use SINE

\[\sin 70° = \frac{h}{15}\] \[h = 15 \sin 70°\] \[h = 15(0.940)\] \[h \approx 14.1 \text{ feet}\]

Answer: The ladder reaches approximately 14.1 feet up the wall.

Check: This makes sense because sin 70° is close to 1, so h should be close to 15 ft. ✓

docs.title: Example 3.10: Finding a Missing Side (Adjacent)
docs.text:
Problem: From a point 50 meters from the base of a building, the angle of elevation to the top is 35°. How tall is the building?

Solution:

Draw and label: - Adjacent (horizontal distance) = 50 m - Angle of elevation = 35° - Opposite (building height) = h (unknown)

Choose ratio: We have adjacent, need opposite → use TANGENT

\[\tan 35° = \frac{h}{50}\] \[h = 50 \tan 35°\] \[h = 50(0.700)\] \[h = 35 \text{ meters}\]

Answer: The building is approximately 35 meters tall.

docs.title: Example 3.11: Multi-Step Problem
docs.text:
Problem: A kite is flying at the end of a 100-meter string. The string makes a 65° angle with the ground. Assuming the string is straight: a) How high is the kite? b) How far horizontally is the kite from the person?

Solution:

Part a: Height (opposite)

\[\sin 65° = \frac{h}{100}\] \[h = 100 \sin 65°\] \[h = 100(0.906) = 90.6 \text{ meters}\]

Part b: Horizontal distance (adjacent)

\[\cos 65° = \frac{d}{100}\] \[d = 100 \cos 65°\] \[d = 100(0.423) = 42.3 \text{ meters}\]

Answers: a) The kite is approximately 90.6 meters high b) The kite is approximately 42.3 meters horizontally from the person

Verification using Pythagorean theorem: \(\(90.6^2 + 42.3^2 = 8208.36 + 1789.29 = 9997.65 \approx 100^2\)\) ✓

docs.title: Example 3.12: Working Backwards to Find an Angle
docs.text:
Problem: A right triangle has sides 8, 15, and 17. If we call the angle opposite the 8-unit side angle A, what is sin A?

Solution:

Relative to angle A: - Opposite = 8 - Hypotenuse = 17

\[\sin A = \frac{8}{17} \approx 0.471\]

Answer: sin A = 8/17 ≈ 0.471

Note: In Chapter 7, we'll learn how to find the actual angle measure (approximately 28.1°) using inverse trigonometric functions.

docs.title: Key Concepts Reviewed
docs.text:
Three Primary Trigonometric Ratios: - Sine: opposite/hypotenuse - Cosine: adjacent/hypotenuse - Tangent: opposite/adjacent

Three Reciprocal Ratios: - Cosecant: hypotenuse/opposite (reciprocal of sine) - Secant: hypotenuse/adjacent (reciprocal of cosine) - Cotangent: adjacent/opposite (reciprocal of tangent)

SOHCAHTOA Mnemonic: - Helps remember the primary ratios - Essential for identifying which ratio to use

Important Relationships: - Complementary angles: sin θ = cos(90° - θ) - Reciprocal relationships: sin θ × csc θ = 1 - Ratios are constant for a given angle regardless of triangle size

docs.title: Important Formulas
docs.text:
Primary Ratios: \(\(\sin \theta = \frac{\text{opp}}{\text{hyp}}, \quad \cos \theta = \frac{\text{adj}}{\text{hyp}}, \quad \tan \theta = \frac{\text{opp}}{\text{adj}}\)\)

Reciprocal Ratios: \(\(\csc \theta = \frac{\text{hyp}}{\text{opp}}, \quad \sec \theta = \frac{\text{hyp}}{\text{adj}}, \quad \cot \theta = \frac{\text{adj}}{\text{opp}}\)\)

docs.title: Why This Matters for Trigonometry
docs.text:
These fundamental ratios are the building blocks of all trigonometry:

  1. Foundation for all trigonometric work - Every advanced concept builds on these basic ratios
  2. Real-world applications - Used in surveying, navigation, engineering, architecture, and physics
  3. Connection between angles and distances - Allows us to find unknown measurements indirectly
  4. Preparation for advanced topics - Understanding these ratios is essential for the unit circle, graphs, and identities

docs.title: Chapter 4: Special Right Triangles and Angle Values
Introduction
docs.text:
Certain right triangles appear so frequently in mathematics, architecture, and nature that they deserve special attention. These special right triangles—the 45-45-90 triangle and the 30-60-90 triangle—have side length ratios that are easy to remember and trigonometric values that are used constantly in mathematics.

In this chapter, you'll learn to recognize these special triangles, understand their properties, and memorize the exact trigonometric values for 30°, 45°, and 60° angles. Unlike most angles, whose trigonometric values require a calculator, these special angles have exact values that involve simple fractions and square roots. Knowing these values by heart will speed up your work and deepen your understanding of trigonometry.

docs.title: Chapter Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After completing this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Remember: Recall side ratios for 45-45-90 and 30-60-90 triangles and exact trig values for special angles
  • Understand: Explain why these triangles have consistent side ratios
  • Apply: Use special triangle properties to solve problems quickly
  • Analyze: Recognize when a problem involves special triangles
  • Evaluate: Verify calculations using special angle values

docs.title: The 45-45-90 Triangle
docs.text:
A 45-45-90 triangle is an isosceles right triangle with two 45° angles and one 90° angle.

Key Properties: - Two legs are equal in length - The two 45° angles are equal - It's half of a square (cut diagonally)

Side Ratio: If each leg has length x, then: - Leg : Leg : Hypotenuse = x : x : x√2

Or simplified: - 1 : 1 : √2

Why this ratio? Using the Pythagorean theorem: \(\(x^2 + x^2 = h^2\)\) \(\(2x^2 = h^2\)\) \(\(h = x\sqrt{2}\)\)

Visual Description: Imagine a square with side length 1. Draw a diagonal. You've created two 45-45-90 triangles, each with legs of 1 and hypotenuse of √2 ≈ 1.414.

docs.title: The 30-60-90 Triangle
docs.text:
A 30-60-90 triangle is a right triangle with angles of 30°, 60°, and 90°.

Key Properties: - It's half of an equilateral triangle (cut vertically) - The side opposite the 30° angle is the shortest - The side opposite the 60° angle is the middle length - The hypotenuse is the longest (opposite the 90° angle)

Side Ratio: If the shortest leg (opposite 30°) has length x, then: - Short leg : Long leg : Hypotenuse = x : x√3 : 2x

Or simplified: - 1 : √3 : 2

Why this ratio? Start with an equilateral triangle (all sides length 2, all angles 60°). Drop a perpendicular from one vertex to the opposite side, creating two 30-60-90 triangles: - Hypotenuse: 2 (original side) - Short leg: 1 (half the base) - Long leg: √3 (by Pythagorean theorem: √(2² - 1²) = √3)

docs.title: Memorizing the Ratios
docs.text:
45-45-90: Think "1, 1, root 2" - Both legs equal - Hypotenuse is leg × √2

30-60-90: Think "1, root 3, 2" - Shortest leg: 1 (opposite 30°) - Middle leg: √3 (opposite 60°) - Hypotenuse: 2 (opposite 90°)

Memory Tip: The 30-60-90 ratio goes in increasing order: 1, √3 (≈1.73), 2

docs.title: Finding Actual Side Lengths
docs.text:
When you know one side of a special triangle, you can find all sides using the ratios.

Strategy: 1. Identify the type of special triangle 2. Determine which side you know (short leg, long leg, or hypotenuse) 3. Set up a proportion using the ratio 4. Solve for the unknowns

docs.title: Example 4.1: Working with 45-45-90 Triangles
docs.text:
Problem: An isosceles right triangle has legs of 6 cm. Find the length of the hypotenuse.

Solution:

This is a 45-45-90 triangle with the ratio 1 : 1 : √2

If each leg = 6 cm, then using the ratio: \(\(\frac{\text{leg}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)\)

\[\frac{6}{h} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\] \[h = 6\sqrt{2} \text{ cm}\]

Or more directly: hypotenuse = leg × √2 = 6√2 cm

Answer: The hypotenuse is 6√2 ≈ 8.49 cm.

Verification: Using Pythagorean theorem: \(\(6^2 + 6^2 = 36 + 36 = 72\)\) \(\((6\sqrt{2})^2 = 36(2) = 72\)\) ✓

docs.title: Example 4.2: Finding Legs from Hypotenuse (45-45-90)
docs.text:
Problem: A 45-45-90 triangle has a hypotenuse of 10 inches. Find the length of each leg.

Solution:

Using the ratio 1 : 1 : √2

If hypotenuse = 10, then: \(\(\text{leg} \times \sqrt{2} = 10\)\)

\[\text{leg} = \frac{10}{\sqrt{2}}\]

Rationalizing the denominator: \(\(\text{leg} = \frac{10}{\sqrt{2}} \times \frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{10\sqrt{2}}{2} = 5\sqrt{2} \text{ inches}\)\)

Answer: Each leg is 5√2 ≈ 7.07 inches.

docs.title: Example 4.3: Working with 30-60-90 Triangles
docs.text:
Problem: In a 30-60-90 triangle, the shorter leg (opposite 30°) is 5 meters. Find the other leg and the hypotenuse.

Solution:

Using the ratio 1 : √3 : 2

If short leg = 5 m, then we scale the entire ratio by 5: - Short leg: 5 m (given) - Long leg: 5√3 m - Hypotenuse: 10 m

Answer: - Long leg = 5√3 ≈ 8.66 meters - Hypotenuse = 10 meters

Verification: Using Pythagorean theorem: \(\(5^2 + (5\sqrt{3})^2 = 25 + 75 = 100 = 10^2\)\) ✓

docs.title: Example 4.4: Finding Other Sides from Hypotenuse (30-60-90)
docs.text:
Problem: A 30-60-90 triangle has a hypotenuse of 12 cm. Find both legs.

Solution:

Using the ratio 1 : √3 : 2

If hypotenuse = 12, then we scale the ratio: \(\(2x = 12\)\) \(\(x = 6\)\)

Therefore: - Short leg: 6 cm - Long leg: 6√3 cm - Hypotenuse: 12 cm (given)

Answer: - Short leg (opposite 30°) = 6 cm - Long leg (opposite 60°) = 6√3 ≈ 10.39 cm

docs.title: Exact Trigonometric Values for Special Angles
docs.text: For the angles 30°, 45°, and 60°, we can determine exact trigonometric values using our special triangles.

docs.title: Values from the 45-45-90 Triangle
docs.text:
Using a 45-45-90 triangle with legs of 1 and hypotenuse of √2:

For 45°: \(\(\sin 45° = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\)\)

\[\cos 45° = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\] \[\tan 45° = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}} = \frac{1}{1} = 1\]

Note: sin 45° = cos 45° because the triangle is isosceles!

docs.title: Reference Table of Special Angle Values
Patterns to Notice
docs.text:
1. Sine increases, cosine decreases as the angle increases from 30° to 60°
  2. Complementary pairs: sin 30° = cos 60° and sin 60° = cos 30°
  3. 45° is symmetrical: sin 45° = cos 45°
  4. Tangent pattern: tan 30° < 1, tan 45° = 1, tan 60° > 1

docs.title: Alternative Forms
docs.text:
Some values can be written in different equivalent forms:

√2/2 is equivalent to 1/√2 (rationalized form is preferred)

√3/3 is equivalent to 1/√3 (rationalized form is preferred)

docs.title: Reciprocal Values
docs.text:
You can also find exact values for cosecant, secant, and cotangent:

For 45°: - csc 45° = √2 - sec 45° = √2 - cot 45° = 1

For 30°: - csc 30° = 2 - sec 30° = 2√3/3 - cot 30° = √3

For 60°: - csc 60° = 2√3/3 - sec 60° = 2 - cot 60° = √3/3

docs.title: Example 4.5: Evaluating Expressions with Special Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Evaluate without a calculator: sin 30° + cos 60°

Solution:

From the reference table: - sin 30° = 1/2 - cos 60° = 1/2

\[\sin 30° + \cos 60° = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} = 1\]

Answer: 1

Note: This makes sense because sin 30° = cos 60° (cofunction identity for complementary angles).

docs.title: Example 4.6: Using Special Values in Equations
docs.text:
Problem: Solve for x: x · tan 60° = 12

Solution:

From the reference table: tan 60° = √3

\[x \cdot \sqrt{3} = 12\] \[x = \frac{12}{\sqrt{3}}\]

Rationalizing: \(\(x = \frac{12}{\sqrt{3}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{12\sqrt{3}}{3} = 4\sqrt{3}\)\)

Answer: x = 4√3 ≈ 6.93

docs.title: Example 4.7: Verifying Trigonometric Identities with Special Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Verify that sin² 30° + cos² 30° = 1

Solution:

From the reference table: - sin 30° = 1/2 - cos 30° = √3/2

\[\sin^2 30° + \cos^2 30° = \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2\]

\(\(= \frac{1}{4} + \frac{3}{4} = \frac{4}{4} = 1\)\) ✓

Answer: Identity verified!

Note: This is an example of the Pythagorean identity (which we'll study in Chapter 6).

docs.title: Example 4.8: Application with Special Angles
docs.text:
Problem: A 30-foot ladder leans against a wall at a 60° angle with the ground. How high up the wall does it reach?

Solution:

This creates a 30-60-90 triangle: - Hypotenuse (ladder) = 30 ft - Angle with ground = 60° - Height = opposite side

\[\sin 60° = \frac{h}{30}\] \[\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \frac{h}{30}\] \[h = 30 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = 15\sqrt{3} \text{ feet}\]

Answer: The ladder reaches 15√3 ≈ 25.98 feet up the wall.

docs.title: Chapter 5: The Unit Circle and Trigonometric Functions
Introduction
docs.text:
So far, we've studied trigonometric ratios only in the context of right triangles with acute angles. But what about angles greater than 90°? What about negative angles? To answer these questions, we need a more powerful tool: the unit circle.

The unit circle is a circle with radius 1 centered at the origin of a coordinate plane. It provides a elegant way to extend trigonometric functions to any angle and reveals beautiful patterns in how these functions behave. The unit circle is also the key to understanding the graphs of trigonometric functions, which describe wave patterns found throughout nature—from sound waves to ocean tides to the motion of planets.

docs.title: Chapter Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After completing this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Remember: Recall the definition of the unit circle and key angle positions
  • Understand: Explain how trigonometric functions extend beyond acute angles
  • Apply: Find trigonometric values using the unit circle
  • Analyze: Identify patterns in the behavior of trigonometric functions
  • Evaluate: Determine domains, ranges, and key features of trig function graphs
  • Create: Sketch graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent functions

docs.title: What Is the Unit Circle?
docs.text:
The unit circle is a circle with: - Center at the origin (0, 0) of a coordinate plane - Radius of exactly 1 unit

Equation: x² + y² = 1

This equation comes directly from the Pythagorean theorem: the distance from the origin to any point (x, y) on the circle is 1.

docs.title: Angles in Standard Position
docs.text:
An angle is in standard position when: - Its vertex is at the origin - Its initial side lies along the positive x-axis - It opens counterclockwise (for positive angles) or clockwise (for negative angles)

Measuring Angles: - Start at the positive x-axis (the "3 o'clock" position) - Rotate counterclockwise for positive angles - Rotate clockwise for negative angles - One complete rotation = 360°

docs.title: Quadrants
docs.text: The coordinate plane is divided into four quadrants: - Quadrant I: Both x and y are positive (0° to 90°) - Quadrant II: x is negative, y is positive (90° to 180°) - Quadrant III: Both x and y are negative (180° to 270°) - Quadrant IV: x is positive, y is negative (270° to 360°)

docs.title: Reference Angles
docs.text:
A reference angle is the acute angle formed between the terminal side of an angle and the x-axis.

Finding Reference Angles: - Quadrant I: reference angle = the angle itself - Quadrant II: reference angle = 180° - angle - Quadrant III: reference angle = angle - 180° - Quadrant IV: reference angle = 360° - angle

Reference angles are always between 0° and 90° and help us find trigonometric values for any angle.

docs.title: Coordinates on the Unit Circle
docs.text:
For any angle θ in standard position, the point where the terminal side intersects the unit circle has coordinates:

(x, y) = (cos θ, sin θ)

This is the fundamental connection between the unit circle and trigonometric functions!

Why this works: - The radius of the unit circle is 1 - cos θ = adjacent/hypotenuse = x/1 = x - sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse = y/1 = y

docs.title: Example 5.1: Identifying Quadrants
docs.text:
Problem: In which quadrant does each angle terminate? a) 135° b) 250° c) -45° d) 400°

Solution:

a) 135°: Between 90° and 180° → Quadrant II

b) 250°: Between 180° and 270° → Quadrant III

c) -45°: Negative, so rotate clockwise 45° from positive x-axis → Quadrant IV

d) 400°: More than 360°, so subtract 360°: 400° - 360° = 40° → Quadrant I

docs.title: Example 5.2: Finding Reference Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Find the reference angle for each: a) 150° b) 225° c) 310°

Solution:

a) 150° is in Quadrant II Reference angle = 180° - 150° = 30°

b) 225° is in Quadrant III Reference angle = 225° - 180° = 45°

c) 310° is in Quadrant IV Reference angle = 360° - 310° = 50°

docs.title: Example 5.3: Using Coordinates to Find Trig Values
docs.text:
Problem: A point on the unit circle at angle θ has coordinates (3/5, 4/5). Find sin θ, cos θ, and tan θ.

Solution:

On the unit circle, (x, y) = (cos θ, sin θ)

Therefore: - cos θ = 3/5 - sin θ = 4/5 - tan θ = sin θ / cos θ = (4/5) / (3/5) = 4/3

Answer: - sin θ = 4/5 - cos θ = 3/5 - tan θ = 4/3

Verification: x² + y² = (3/5)² + (4/5)² = 9/25 + 16/25 = 25/25 = 1 ✓

docs.title: Example 5.4: Special Angles on the Unit Circle
docs.text:
Problem: Find the coordinates on the unit circle for angles 0°, 90°, 180°, and 270°.

Solution:

These are the quadrantal angles (on the axes):

  • 0°: Point (1, 0) → cos 0° = 1, sin 0° = 0
  • 90°: Point (0, 1) → cos 90° = 0, sin 90° = 1
  • 180°: Point (-1, 0) → cos 180° = -1, sin 180° = 0
  • 270°: Point (0, -1) → cos 270° = 0, sin 270° = -1

Note: At these angles, one coordinate is always 0 and the other is ±1.

docs.title: Extending Beyond Right Triangles
docs.text:
The unit circle allows us to define trigonometric functions for any angle, not just acute angles in right triangles.

Definitions for Any Angle θ:

If (x, y) is the point where the terminal side of θ intersects the unit circle:

\[\sin heta = y$$ $$\cos heta = x$$ $$ an heta = rac{y}{x} ext{ (when } x eq 0 ext{)}\]

Reciprocal Functions: \(\(\csc heta = rac{1}{y} ext{ (when } y eq 0 ext{)}\)\) \(\(\sec heta = rac{1}{x} ext{ (when } x eq 0 ext{)}\)\) \(\(\cot heta = rac{x}{y} ext{ (when } y eq 0 ext{)}\)\)

docs.title: Signs of Trigonometric Functions by Quadrant
docs.text:
The sign (positive or negative) of trig functions depends on which quadrant the angle is in:

Quadrant I: All functions positive Quadrant II: Only sine (and csc) positive Quadrant III: Only tangent (and cot) positive Quadrant IV: Only cosine (and sec) positive

Memory device: "All Students Take Calculus" - All (Quadrant I) - Sine (Quadrant II) - Tangent (Quadrant III) - Cosine (Quadrant IV)

docs.title: Domain and Range
docs.text:
Sine and Cosine: - Domain: All real numbers (any angle) - Range: [-1, 1] (values on the unit circle never exceed 1 in magnitude)

Tangent: - Domain: All real numbers except 90° + 180°k (where k is any integer) - Range: All real numbers (tangent can be any value)

Cotangent: - Domain: All real numbers except 180°k - Range: All real numbers

Secant: - Domain: All real numbers except 90° + 180°k - Range: (-∞, -1] ∪ [1, ∞)

Cosecant: - Domain: All real numbers except 180°k - Range: (-∞, -1] ∪ [1, ∞)

docs.text: Strategy: 1. Find the reference angle 2. Determine the trig function value for the reference angle 3. Adjust the sign based on the quadrant

docs.title: Example 5.5: Finding Trig Values for Angles Greater than 90°
docs.text:
Problem: Find sin 150°, cos 150°, and tan 150°.

Solution:

Step 1: 150° is in Quadrant II Reference angle = 180° - 150° = 30°

Step 2: Find values for 30°: - sin 30° = 1/2 - cos 30° = √3/2 - tan 30° = √3/3

Step 3: Apply signs for Quadrant II (only sine positive): - sin 150° = +1/2 = 1/2 - cos 150° = -√3/2 = -√3/2 - tan 150° = -√3/3 = -√3/3

Answer: - sin 150° = 1/2 - cos 150° = -√3/2 - tan 150° = -√3/3

docs.title: Example 5.6: Working with Negative Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Find sin(-60°), cos(-60°), and tan(-60°).

Solution:

-60° rotates 60° clockwise, ending in Quadrant IV.

Reference angle = 60°

Values for 60°: - sin 60° = √3/2 - cos 60° = 1/2 - tan 60° = √3

In Quadrant IV (only cosine positive): - sin(-60°) = -√3/2 - cos(-60°) = 1/2 - tan(-60°) = -√3

Answer: - sin(-60°) = -√3/2 - cos(-60°) = 1/2 - tan(-60°) = -√3

docs.title: Example 5.7: Finding Trig Values for Angles Greater than 360°
docs.text:
Problem: Find sin 495°.

Solution:

Step 1: Reduce to an equivalent angle between 0° and 360°: 495° - 360° = 135°

Step 2: 135° is in Quadrant II Reference angle = 180° - 135° = 45°

Step 3: sin 45° = √2/2

Step 4: In Quadrant II, sine is positive: sin 135° = √2/2

Answer: sin 495° = √2/2

docs.title: Example 5.8: Using the "All Students Take Calculus" Rule
docs.text:
Problem: In which quadrant is θ if sin θ > 0 and cos θ < 0?

Solution:

Sine positive: Quadrants I or II Cosine negative: Quadrants II or III

The quadrant where both conditions are met: Quadrant II

Alternative reasoning: Using "All Students Take Calculus": - Only sine is positive in Quadrant II ✓

docs.title: The Sine Function Graph
docs.text:
The graph of y = sin θ is a wave that: - Oscillates between -1 and 1 - Has a period of 360° (repeats every 360°) - Passes through the origin (0, 0) - Reaches maximum (1) at 90° - Reaches minimum (-1) at 270°

Key Points (one period): - (0°, 0) - (90°, 1) - (180°, 0) - (270°, -1) - (360°, 0)

Shape: Smooth, continuous wave called a sinusoid or sine wave

docs.title: The Cosine Function Graph
docs.text:
The graph of y = cos θ is a wave that: - Oscillates between -1 and 1 - Has a period of 360° (repeats every 360°) - Starts at maximum (1) when θ = 0° - Crosses zero at 90° and 270° - Reaches minimum (-1) at 180°

Key Points (one period): - (0°, 1) - (90°, 0) - (180°, -1) - (270°, 0) - (360°, 1)

Relationship to Sine: The cosine graph is the sine graph shifted left by 90°.

docs.title: The Tangent Function Graph
docs.text:
The graph of y = tan θ: - Has a period of 180° (repeats every 180°) - Has vertical asymptotes at 90°, 270°, etc. (where cosine = 0) - Passes through the origin - Increases from -∞ to +∞ within each period - Has no maximum or minimum values

Key Points: - (0°, 0) - (45°, 1) - (135°, -1) - Undefined at 90°, 270°, etc.

Shape: Repeating curves separated by vertical asymptotes

docs.title: Properties of Trig Function Graphs
docs.text:
Amplitude: The height from the center line to the maximum (for sine and cosine: amplitude = 1)

Period: The horizontal length of one complete cycle - Sine and cosine: 360° - Tangent: 180°

Midline: The horizontal center line (for basic functions: y = 0)

Phase shift: Horizontal shift left or right (basic functions: no shift)

Vertical shift: Shift up or down (basic functions: no shift)

docs.title: Example 5.9: Reading Values from a Sine Graph
docs.text:
Problem: Using the graph of y = sin θ, estimate sin 45° and sin 225°.

Solution:

sin 45°: - 45° is halfway between 0° and 90° - The sine graph rises from 0 at 0° to 1 at 90° - At 45°, it's approximately 0.707 (which equals √2/2)

sin 225°: - 225° is in Quadrant III (between 180° and 270°) - The sine graph goes from 0 at 180° to -1 at 270° - At 225° (halfway), it's approximately -0.707 (which equals -√2/2)

docs.title: Example 5.10: Identifying Key Features
docs.text:
Problem: For the function y = cos θ: a) What is the amplitude? b) What is the period? c) What is the range? d) At what angles between 0° and 360° does cos θ = 0?

Solution:

a) Amplitude = 1 (distance from midline to maximum)

b) Period = 360° (one complete cycle)

c) Range = [-1, 1] (oscillates between -1 and 1)

d) cos θ = 0 at the quarter and three-quarter marks: - θ = 90° and 270°

docs.title: Example 5.11: Comparing Sine and Cosine Graphs
docs.text:
Problem: How is the graph of y = cos θ related to y = sin θ?

Solution:

The cosine graph is the sine graph shifted left by 90°.

Mathematically: cos θ = sin(θ + 90°)

Key differences: - Sine starts at 0; cosine starts at 1 - Sine reaches maximum at 90°; cosine reaches maximum at 0° - Both have the same amplitude, period, and range

Answer: y = cos θ is a horizontal shift of y = sin θ by 90° to the left.

docs.title: Example 5.12: Understanding Tangent Asymptotes
docs.text:
Problem: Why does the tangent function have vertical asymptotes at 90° and 270°?

Solution:

Tangent is defined as: \(\(\tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\)\)

At 90° and 270°, cos θ = 0, which makes the denominator zero.

Division by zero is undefined, so tan θ has vertical asymptotes at these angles.

As θ approaches 90° from the left, tan θ → +∞ As θ approaches 90° from the right, tan θ → -∞

Answer: Vertical asymptotes occur wherever the denominator (cos θ) equals zero.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
A trigonometric identity is an equation involving trigonometric functions that is true for all values of the variable (where both sides are defined). These identities are not just mathematical curiosities—they're essential tools for simplifying expressions, solving equations, and proving other mathematical relationships.

Think of identities as the "algebra" of trigonometry. Just as you use algebraic rules like the distributive property to simplify expressions, you'll use trigonometric identities to transform complex trig expressions into simpler forms. Engineers use these identities to analyze alternating current circuits, physicists use them to describe wave interference, and mathematicians use them to solve otherwise intractable equations.

  • Understand: Explain why identities are true using the unit circle and algebra

docs.title: The Pythagorean Identity
docs.text:
The most fundamental trigonometric identity comes directly from the unit circle equation x² + y² = 1:

\[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\]

This is called the Pythagorean identity because it's based on the Pythagorean theorem.

Alternative forms (by algebraic rearrangement): \(\(\sin^2 \theta = 1 - \cos^2 \theta\)\) \(\(\cos^2 \theta = 1 - \sin^2 \theta\)\)

Extended Pythagorean Identities:

Dividing the basic identity by cos² θ: \(\(\tan^2 \theta + 1 = \sec^2 \theta\)\)

Dividing the basic identity by sin² θ: \(\(1 + \cot^2 \theta = \csc^2 \theta\)\)

docs.title: Quotient Identities
docs.text:
These define tangent and cotangent in terms of sine and cosine:

\[\tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\] \[\cot \theta = \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta}\]

docs.title: Reciprocal Identities
docs.text:
These relate the three primary functions to their reciprocals:

\[\csc \theta = \frac{1}{\sin \theta}, \quad \sin \theta = \frac{1}{\csc \theta}\] \[\sec \theta = \frac{1}{\cos \theta}, \quad \cos \theta = \frac{1}{\sec \theta}\] \[\cot \theta = \frac{1}{\tan \theta}, \quad \tan \theta = \frac{1}{\cot \theta}\]

docs.title: Even-Odd Identities
docs.text:
These describe the symmetry of trig functions:

Odd functions (symmetric about the origin): \(\(\sin(-\theta) = -\sin \theta\)\) \(\(\tan(-\theta) = -\tan \theta\)\) \(\(\cot(-\theta) = -\cot \theta\)\) \(\(\csc(-\theta) = -\csc \theta\)\)

Even function (symmetric about the y-axis): \(\(\cos(-\theta) = \cos \theta\)\) \(\(\sec(-\theta) = \sec \theta\)\)

Why these matter: They tell us how trig functions behave with negative angles.

docs.title: Cofunction Identities
docs.text:
These relate complementary angles (angles that sum to 90°):

\[\sin \theta = \cos(90° - \theta)$$ $$\cos \theta = \sin(90° - \theta)$$ $$\tan \theta = \cot(90° - \theta)$$ $$\cot \theta = \tan(90° - \theta)$$ $$\sec \theta = \csc(90° - \theta)$$ $$\csc \theta = \sec(90° - \theta)\]

Meaning: The sine of an angle equals the cosine of its complement.

docs.title: Example 6.1: Using the Pythagorean Identity
docs.text:
Problem: If sin θ = 3/5 and θ is in Quadrant I, find cos θ.

Solution:

Using the Pythagorean identity: \(\(\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\)\)

\[\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^2 + \cos^2 \theta = 1\] \[\frac{9}{25} + \cos^2 \theta = 1\] \[\cos^2 \theta = 1 - \frac{9}{25} = \frac{16}{25}\] \[\cos \theta = \pm\frac{4}{5}\]

Since θ is in Quadrant I (where cosine is positive): \(\(\cos \theta = \frac{4}{5}\)\)

Answer: cos θ = 4/5

docs.title: Example 6.2: Simplifying Using Quotient Identity
docs.text:
Problem: Simplify: \(\frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} + \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta}\)

Solution:

Recognize the quotient identities: \(\(\frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} = \tan \theta\)\)

\[\frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta} = \cot \theta\]

So the expression becomes: \(\(\tan \theta + \cot \theta\)\)

We can also find a common denominator: \(\(\frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} + \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta} = \frac{\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta}{\sin \theta \cos \theta}\)\)

Using the Pythagorean identity (sin² θ + cos² θ = 1): \(\(= \frac{1}{\sin \theta \cos \theta}\)\)

Answer: \(\tan \theta + \cot \theta = \frac{1}{\sin \theta \cos \theta}\)

docs.title: Example 6.3: Using Even-Odd Identities
docs.text:
Problem: Simplify: sin(-30°) + cos(-30°)

Solution:

Using even-odd identities: - sin(-30°) = -sin 30° = -1/2 - cos(-30°) = cos 30° = √3/2

\[\sin(-30°) + \cos(-30°) = -\frac{1}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \frac{\sqrt{3} - 1}{2}\]

Answer: \(\frac{\sqrt{3} - 1}{2}\) ≈ 0.366

docs.title: Example 6.4: Verifying an Identity
docs.text:
Problem: Verify the identity: \(\sin \theta \tan \theta = \sec \theta - \cos \theta\)

Solution:

Work with the left side, converting to sine and cosine: \(\(\sin \theta \tan \theta = \sin \theta \cdot \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} = \frac{\sin^2 \theta}{\cos \theta}\)\)

Use the Pythagorean identity: sin² θ = 1 - cos² θ \(\(= \frac{1 - \cos^2 \theta}{\cos \theta}\)\)

Separate the fraction: \(\(= \frac{1}{\cos \theta} - \frac{\cos^2 \theta}{\cos \theta} = \sec \theta - \cos \theta\)\)

This matches the right side, so the identity is verified! ✓

docs.title: Sum and Difference Formulas
docs.text:
These formulas allow us to find exact trig values for sums and differences of angles:

Sine Sum and Difference: \(\(\sin(A + B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B\)\) \(\(\sin(A - B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B\)\)

Cosine Sum and Difference: \(\(\cos(A + B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B\)\) \(\(\cos(A - B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B\)\)

Tangent Sum and Difference: \(\(\tan(A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}\)\) \(\(\tan(A - B) = \frac{\tan A - \tan B}{1 + \tan A \tan B}\)\)

Important: Note that sin(A + B) ≠ sin A + sin B. You must use the formula!

docs.title: Double Angle Formulas
docs.text:
These are special cases of the sum formulas where B = A:

Sine Double Angle: \(\(\sin 2\theta = 2\sin \theta \cos \theta\)\)

Cosine Double Angle (three equivalent forms): \(\(\cos 2\theta = \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta\)\) \(\(\cos 2\theta = 2\cos^2 \theta - 1\)\) \(\(\cos 2\theta = 1 - 2\sin^2 \theta\)\)

Tangent Double Angle: \(\(\tan 2\theta = \frac{2\tan \theta}{1 - \tan^2 \theta}\)\)

docs.title: Half Angle Formulas
docs.text:
These formulas find trig values of half an angle:

\[\sin \frac{\theta}{2} = \pm\sqrt{\frac{1 - \cos \theta}{2}}\] \[\cos \frac{\theta}{2} = \pm\sqrt{\frac{1 + \cos \theta}{2}}\] \[\tan \frac{\theta}{2} = \pm\sqrt{\frac{1 - \cos \theta}{1 + \cos \theta}} = \frac{\sin \theta}{1 + \cos \theta} = \frac{1 - \cos \theta}{\sin \theta}\]

The ± sign is determined by the quadrant of θ/2.

docs.title: Product-to-Sum Formulas
docs.text:
These convert products of trig functions to sums:

\[\sin A \cos B = \frac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]\] \[\cos A \sin B = \frac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]\] \[\cos A \cos B = \frac{1}{2}[\cos(A+B) + \cos(A-B)]\] \[\sin A \sin B = \frac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]\]

docs.title: Example 6.5: Using Sum Formula to Find Exact Value
docs.text:
Problem: Find the exact value of sin 75° without a calculator.

Solution:

Write 75° as a sum of special angles: 75° = 45° + 30°

Using the sine sum formula: \(\(\sin(A + B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B\)\)

\[\sin 75° = \sin(45° + 30°)$$ $$= \sin 45° \cos 30° + \cos 45° \sin 30°$$ $$= \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}$$ $$= \frac{\sqrt{6}}{4} + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}$$ $$= \frac{\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2}}{4}\]

Answer: \(\sin 75° = \frac{\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2}}{4}\) ≈ 0.966

docs.title: Example 6.6: Using Difference Formula
docs.text:
Problem: Find the exact value of cos 15°.

Solution:

Write 15° as a difference: 15° = 45° - 30°

Using the cosine difference formula: \(\(\cos(A - B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B\)\)

\[\cos 15° = \cos(45° - 30°)$$ $$= \cos 45° \cos 30° + \sin 45° \sin 30°$$ $$= \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}$$ $$= \frac{\sqrt{6}}{4} + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}$$ $$= \frac{\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2}}{4}\]

Answer: \(\cos 15° = \frac{\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2}}{4}\) ≈ 0.966

docs.title: Example 6.7: Using Double Angle Formula
docs.text:
Problem: If sin θ = 3/5 and θ is in Quadrant II, find sin 2θ.

Solution:

First, find cos θ using the Pythagorean identity: \(\(\cos^2 \theta = 1 - \sin^2 \theta = 1 - \frac{9}{25} = \frac{16}{25}\)\)

In Quadrant II, cosine is negative: \(\(\cos \theta = -\frac{4}{5}\)\)

Now use the double angle formula: \(\(\sin 2\theta = 2\sin \theta \cos \theta\)\) \(\(= 2 \cdot \frac{3}{5} \cdot \left(-\frac{4}{5}\right)\)\) \(\(= -\frac{24}{25}\)\)

Answer: sin 2θ = -24/25

docs.title: Example 6.8: Using Half Angle Formula
docs.text:
Problem: Find sin 15° using a half angle formula.

Solution:

Note that 15° = 30°/2

Using the half angle formula: \(\(\sin \frac{\theta}{2} = \sqrt{\frac{1 - \cos \theta}{2}}\)\)

\[\sin 15° = \sin \frac{30°}{2} = \sqrt{\frac{1 - \cos 30°}{2}}\] \[= \sqrt{\frac{1 - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}}{2}} = \sqrt{\frac{2 - \sqrt{3}}{4}}\] \[= \frac{\sqrt{2 - \sqrt{3}}}{2}\]

Answer: \(\sin 15° = \frac{\sqrt{2 - \sqrt{3}}}{2}\) ≈ 0.259

Note: This is a different form than we got in Example 6.6 for cos 15°, but both are correct!

docs.title: Example 6.9: Simplifying Using Double Angle Formula
docs.text:
Problem: Simplify: \(\frac{\sin 2\theta}{2\sin \theta}\)

Solution:

Use the double angle formula for sine: \(\(\sin 2\theta = 2\sin \theta \cos \theta\)\)

Substitute: \(\(\frac{\sin 2\theta}{2\sin \theta} = \frac{2\sin \theta \cos \theta}{2\sin \theta}\)\)

Cancel common factors: \(\(= \cos \theta\)\)

Answer: \(\frac{\sin 2\theta}{2\sin \theta} = \cos \theta\)

docs.title: Key Identities to Memorize
docs.text:
Pythagorean Identities: - \(\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\) - \(\tan^2 \theta + 1 = \sec^2 \theta\) - \(1 + \cot^2 \theta = \csc^2 \theta\)

Quotient Identities: - \(\tan \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\) - \(\cot \theta = \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta}\)

Reciprocal Identities: - \(\csc \theta = \frac{1}{\sin \theta}\), \(\sec \theta = \frac{1}{\cos \theta}\), \(\cot \theta = \frac{1}{\tan \theta}\)

Even-Odd Identities: - \(\sin(-\theta) = -\sin \theta\) (odd) - \(\cos(-\theta) = \cos \theta\) (even) - \(\tan(-\theta) = -\tan \theta\) (odd)

Sum and Difference: - \(\sin(A \pm B) = \sin A \cos B \pm \cos A \sin B\) - \(\cos(A \pm B) = \cos A \cos B \mp \sin A \sin B\)

Double Angle: - \(\sin 2\theta = 2\sin \theta \cos \theta\) - \(\cos 2\theta = \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta = 2\cos^2 \theta - 1 = 1 - 2\sin^2 \theta\)

docs.title: Strategies for Using Identities
docs.text:
Simplification: 1. Convert everything to sine and cosine 2. Look for Pythagorean identity opportunities 3. Factor when possible 4. Find common denominators for fractions

Verification: 1. Work with one side (usually the more complex side) 2. Transform it step-by-step 3. Each step should use a valid identity or algebraic operation 4. Stop when you reach the other side

Finding Exact Values: 1. Express the angle as a sum, difference, or multiple of special angles 2. Apply the appropriate formula 3. Use known values for 30°, 45°, 60°

docs.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
docs.text:
1. Don't distribute incorrectly: sin(A + B) ≠ sin A + sin B
  2. Watch signs: Negative angles and different quadrants affect signs
  3. Verify domain restrictions: Some identities require certain conditions
  4. Don't skip steps: Show each transformation clearly
  5. Check your algebra: Factor correctly, combine fractions properly

docs.title: Why This Matters for Trigonometry
docs.text:
Trigonometric identities are essential because:

  1. Simplification - Complex expressions become manageable
  2. Equation solving - Many trig equations can only be solved using identities
  3. Integration and differentiation - Calculus relies heavily on these identities
  4. Engineering applications - Signal processing, wave analysis, and AC circuits
  5. Exact values - Find precise values for any angle built from special angles
  6. Proof and derivation - Establish new mathematical relationships

docs.title: Chapter 7: Solving Right Triangles and Finding Angles
Introduction
docs.text:
So far, you've learned to find trigonometric ratios when you know the angle. But what if you know the ratio and need to find the angle? Or what if you know only some sides and need to find all the angles? This chapter introduces inverse trigonometric functions, which allow us to work backwards from ratios to angles.

We'll also put together everything we've learned to solve right triangles—finding all unknown sides and angles when given partial information. This skill is fundamental to surveying, navigation, engineering, and architecture. Finally, we'll learn to solve trigonometric equations, finding all angles that satisfy a given condition.

docs.title: Chapter Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After completing this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Remember: Recall definitions of inverse trigonometric functions
  • Understand: Explain the relationship between trig functions and their inverses
  • Apply: Solve right triangles completely given partial information
  • Analyze: Determine which methods and formulas to use for different problems
  • Evaluate: Find all solutions to trigonometric equations
  • Create: Set up and solve multi-step real-world problems

docs.title: What Does It Mean to "Solve" a Triangle?
docs.text: To solve a triangle means to find all unknown sides and angles. For a right triangle: - One angle is always 90° - The other two angles sum to 90° (complementary) - If you know two sides, you can find the third (Pythagorean theorem) - If you know one angle and one side, you can find everything else (trig ratios)

docs.title: Minimum Information Needed
docs.text:
To solve a right triangle, you need: - One side and one acute angle, OR - Two sides (any two of the three)

The right angle (90°) is usually given.

docs.title: General Strategy for Solving Right Triangles
docs.text:
Given one side and one angle: 1. Find the third angle (subtract from 90°) 2. Use trig ratios to find the other sides 3. Verify using the Pythagorean theorem

Given two sides: 1. Find the third side (Pythagorean theorem) 2. Use trig ratios to find one angle 3. Find the other angle (subtract from 90°)

docs.title: Choosing the Right Ratio
docs.text: Decision guide: - If you know hypotenuse and need opposite/adjacent → use sine/cosine - If you know both legs → use tangent to find angles - If you know one leg and hypotenuse → use sine or cosine - If you know both legs and need hypotenuse → use Pythagorean theorem

docs.title: Example 7.1: Solving Given One Side and One Angle
docs.text:
Problem: In right triangle ABC with right angle at C, angle A = 35° and side AC (adjacent to angle A) = 12 cm. Find all other sides and angles.

Solution:

Given: - Right angle at C (90°) - Angle A = 35° - Adjacent side (AC) = 12 cm

Step 1: Find angle B \(\(B = 90° - 35° = 55°\)\)

Step 2: Find opposite side (BC) using tangent \(\(\tan 35° = \frac{BC}{12}\)\) \(\(BC = 12 \tan 35°\)\) \(\(BC = 12(0.700) \approx 8.40 \text{ cm}\)\)

Step 3: Find hypotenuse (AB) using cosine \(\(\cos 35° = \frac{12}{AB}\)\) \(\(AB = \frac{12}{\cos 35°}\)\) \(\(AB = \frac{12}{0.819} \approx 14.65 \text{ cm}\)\)

Verification: Check with Pythagorean theorem \(\(12^2 + 8.40^2 = 144 + 70.56 = 214.56\)\) \(\(14.65^2 = 214.62\)\) ✓ (slight difference due to rounding)

Answer: - Angle B = 55° - Side BC ≈ 8.40 cm - Side AB ≈ 14.65 cm

docs.title: Example 7.2: Solving Given Two Sides (Both Legs)
docs.text:
Problem: A right triangle has legs of 9 inches and 12 inches. Find the hypotenuse and both acute angles.

Solution:

Given: - Leg a = 9 inches - Leg b = 12 inches

Step 1: Find hypotenuse using Pythagorean theorem \(\(c^2 = 9^2 + 12^2 = 81 + 144 = 225\)\) \(\(c = 15 \text{ inches}\)\)

Step 2: Find one angle using tangent (we'll find angle A opposite the 9-inch side) \(\(\tan A = \frac{9}{12} = 0.75\)\)

To find A, we need the inverse tangent (covered in next section): \(\(A = \arctan(0.75) \approx 36.87°\)\)

Step 3: Find the other angle \(\(B = 90° - 36.87° = 53.13°\)\)

Answer: - Hypotenuse = 15 inches - Angle A ≈ 36.87° - Angle B ≈ 53.13°

docs.title: Example 7.3: Solving Given Hypotenuse and One Leg
docs.text:
Problem: A right triangle has a hypotenuse of 25 feet and one leg of 15 feet. Find the other leg and both acute angles.

Solution:

Given: - Hypotenuse c = 25 feet - Leg a = 15 feet

Step 1: Find other leg using Pythagorean theorem \(\(15^2 + b^2 = 25^2\)\) \(\(225 + b^2 = 625\)\) \(\(b^2 = 400\)\) \(\(b = 20 \text{ feet}\)\)

Step 2: Find angle A (opposite 15-foot side) using sine \(\(\sin A = \frac{15}{25} = 0.6\)\) \(\(A = \arcsin(0.6) \approx 36.87°\)\)

Step 3: Find angle B \(\(B = 90° - 36.87° = 53.13°\)\)

Answer: - Other leg = 20 feet - Angle A ≈ 36.87° - Angle B ≈ 53.13°

docs.title: Example 7.4: Application Problem
docs.text:
Problem: A 20-foot ladder leans against a building. The base of the ladder is 8 feet from the building. How high up the building does the ladder reach, and what angle does it make with the ground?

Solution:

This forms a right triangle: - Hypotenuse (ladder) = 20 feet - Base (adjacent to ground angle) = 8 feet

Find height (opposite side): \(\(8^2 + h^2 = 20^2\)\) \(\(64 + h^2 = 400\)\) \(\(h^2 = 336\)\) \(\(h = \sqrt{336} \approx 18.33 \text{ feet}\)\)

Find angle with ground: \(\(\cos \theta = \frac{8}{20} = 0.4\)\) \(\(\theta = \arccos(0.4) \approx 66.42°\)\)

Answer: - The ladder reaches approximately 18.33 feet up the building - The ladder makes an angle of approximately 66.42° with the ground

docs.title: What Are Inverse Functions?
docs.text:
An inverse function reverses the operation of a function. If f(x) = y, then f⁻¹(y) = x.

For trigonometry: - If sin θ = 0.5, then arcsin(0.5) = θ - The inverse function takes us from the ratio back to the angle

docs.title: Notation for Inverse Trig Functions
docs.text:
Two equivalent notations:

\[\arcsin x = \sin^{-1} x$$ $$\arccos x = \cos^{-1} x$$ $$\arctan x = \tan^{-1} x\]

Important: sin⁻¹ x does NOT mean 1/sin x. It means the inverse sine function (arcsin).

docs.title: Domains and Ranges of Inverse Functions
docs.text:
For inverse functions to work properly, we restrict their ranges:

Arcsine: - Domain: [-1, 1] - Range: [-90°, 90°] (or [-π/2, π/2] in radians) - Returns angles in Quadrants I and IV

Arccosine: - Domain: [-1, 1] - Range: [0°, 180°] (or [0, π] in radians) - Returns angles in Quadrants I and II

Arctangent: - Domain: All real numbers - Range: (-90°, 90°) (or (-π/2, π/2) in radians) - Returns angles in Quadrants I and IV

docs.title: Calculator Considerations
docs.text: When using a calculator: - Make sure it's in degree mode (or radian mode, depending on context) - The inverse functions return the principal value (one specific angle in the range) - There may be other angles with the same trig value

docs.title: Example 7.5: Basic Inverse Function Evaluation
docs.text:
Problem: Find each angle (in degrees): a) arcsin(1/2) b) arccos(√2/2) c) arctan(1)

Solution:

a) arcsin(1/2): What angle has sine = 1/2? From special angles: sin 30° = 1/2 Answer: 30°

b) arccos(√2/2): What angle has cosine = √2/2? From special angles: cos 45° = √2/2 Answer: 45°

c) arctan(1): What angle has tangent = 1? From special angles: tan 45° = 1 Answer: 45°

docs.title: Example 7.6: Using Calculator for Inverse Functions
docs.text:
Problem: Find the angle θ (in degrees, to two decimal places): a) sin θ = 0.75 b) cos θ = 0.4 c) tan θ = 2.5

Solution:

Using a calculator in degree mode:

a) θ = arcsin(0.75) = 48.59°

b) θ = arccos(0.4) = 66.42°

c) θ = arctan(2.5) = 68.20°

docs.title: Example 7.7: Finding All Solutions in [0°, 360°)
docs.text:
Problem: Find all angles θ in [0°, 360°) where sin θ = 0.5.

Solution:

Step 1: Find the principal value \(\(\theta_1 = \arcsin(0.5) = 30°\)\)

This is in Quadrant I.

Step 2: Sine is also positive in Quadrant II The second solution is: \(\(\theta_2 = 180° - 30° = 150°\)\)

Verification: - sin 30° = 0.5 ✓ - sin 150° = 0.5 ✓

Answer: θ = 30° or 150°

docs.title: Example 7.8: Inverse Functions with Negative Values
docs.text:
Problem: Find arccos(-0.5).

Solution:

We need an angle whose cosine is -0.5.

Cosine is negative in Quadrants II and III, but arccos returns values in [0°, 180°], so it will be in Quadrant II.

The reference angle satisfies cos(ref) = 0.5, so ref = 60°.

In Quadrant II: \(\(\theta = 180° - 60° = 120°\)\)

Answer: arccos(-0.5) = 120°

Verification: cos 120° = -1/2 = -0.5 ✓

docs.title: The Process
docs.text: When you know the ratio of sides in a right triangle: 1. Identify which trig function relates the known sides 2. Use the appropriate inverse function 3. Consider whether other angles also satisfy the condition 4. Check that angles are in the appropriate range for the problem

docs.title: Common Scenarios
docs.text: Given opposite and hypotenuse → use arcsin Given adjacent and hypotenuse → use arccos Given opposite and adjacent → use arctan

docs.title: Multiple Solutions
docs.text:
Remember that: - Sine is positive in Quadrants I and II - Cosine is positive in Quadrants I and IV - Tangent is positive in Quadrants I and III

If a problem asks for all solutions in [0°, 360°), you may need to find two angles.

docs.title: Example 7.9: Finding an Angle Given Two Sides
docs.text:
Problem: In a right triangle, the opposite side is 7 cm and the adjacent side is 10 cm. Find the angle.

Solution:

The ratio of opposite to adjacent suggests using tangent: \(\(\tan \theta = \frac{7}{10} = 0.7\)\)

\[\theta = \arctan(0.7) \approx 34.99°\]

Answer: θ ≈ 35.0°

docs.title: Example 7.10: Using Inverse Functions in Applications
docs.text:
Problem: A person stands 50 meters from a building and looks up at a 65° angle to see the top. How tall is the building?

Solution:

This is actually a forward problem (given angle, find side), but let's solve it:

\[\tan 65° = \frac{h}{50}$$ $$h = 50 \tan 65° \approx 50(2.145) = 107.25 \text{ meters}\]

Reverse question: If the building is 107.25 m tall and you're 50 m away, what's the angle?

\(\(\tan \theta = \frac{107.25}{50} = 2.145\)\) \(\(\theta = \arctan(2.145) \approx 65°\)\) ✓

docs.title: Example 7.11: Finding Angles When Given Special Ratios
docs.text:
Problem: In a right triangle, the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse is 3:5. Find the angle.

Solution:

\[\sin \theta = \frac{3}{5} = 0.6\] \[\theta = \arcsin(0.6) \approx 36.87°\]

Answer: θ ≈ 36.87°

Note: This is the same as the 3-4-5 triangle (scaled), which we could verify: - If opposite = 3 and hypotenuse = 5, then adjacent = 4 (by Pythagorean theorem) - tan θ = 3/4 = 0.75 - arctan(0.75) ≈ 36.87° ✓

docs.text: Linear equations: sin θ = 0.5 Quadratic equations: 2sin² θ - sin θ = 0 Multiple angle equations: sin 2θ = 0.5 Mixed function equations: sin θ = cos θ

docs.title: General Strategy
docs.text:
1. Isolate the trig function (if possible)
  2. Use identities to simplify (if needed)
  3. Solve for the angle using inverse functions
  4. Find all solutions in the specified range
  5. Check solutions in the original equation

docs.title: Using Identities to Solve Equations
docs.text: Sometimes you need to use identities like: - Pythagorean identities - Double angle formulas - Factoring

docs.title: Example 7.12: Solving a Quadratic Trigonometric Equation
docs.text:
Problem: Solve 2sin² θ - sin θ = 0 for θ in [0°, 360°).

Solution:

Factor out sin θ: \(\(\sin \theta(2\sin \theta - 1) = 0\)\)

This gives two equations: \(\(\sin \theta = 0 \quad \text{or} \quad 2\sin \theta - 1 = 0\)\)

From sin θ = 0: θ = 0°, 180°, 360°

From 2sin θ - 1 = 0: \(\(\sin \theta = \frac{1}{2}\)\) θ = 30°, 150°

Answer: θ = 0°, 30°, 150°, 180°, 360°

(Note: Depending on convention, 360° might be excluded since it's the same as 0°)

docs.title: Example 7.13: Solving Equations with Multiple Angles
docs.text:
Problem: Solve sin 2θ = 1/2 for θ in [0°, 180°).

Solution:

Let u = 2θ, then we need sin u = 1/2

From the unit circle: u = 30° or u = 150° (in [0°, 360°))

Since u can range from 0° to 360° when θ ranges from 0° to 180°:

\[2\theta = 30° \Rightarrow \theta = 15°$$ $$2\theta = 150° \Rightarrow \theta = 75°\]

But 2θ could also equal 390° (which is 30° + 360°): \(\(2\theta = 390° \Rightarrow \theta = 195°\)\)

This is outside [0°, 180°), so we don't include it.

Answer: θ = 15° or 75°

docs.title: Example 7.14: Solving Mixed Function Equations
docs.text:
Problem: Solve sin θ = cos θ for θ in [0°, 360°).

Solution:

Method 1: Divide both sides by cos θ: \(\(\frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} = 1\)\) \(\(\tan \theta = 1\)\) θ = 45°, 225°

Method 2: Use the fact that sin θ = cos θ when θ = 45° + 180°k

Answer: θ = 45° or 225°

docs.title: Example 7.15: Using Pythagorean Identity
docs.text:
Problem: Solve 2cos² θ + sin θ = 2 for θ in [0°, 360°).

Solution:

Use the identity cos² θ = 1 - sin² θ: \(\(2(1 - \sin^2 \theta) + \sin \theta = 2\)\) \(\(2 - 2\sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta = 2\)\) \(\(-2\sin^2 \theta + \sin \theta = 0\)\) \(\(\sin \theta(-2\sin \theta + 1) = 0\)\)

From sin θ = 0: θ = 0°, 180°, 360°

From -2sin θ + 1 = 0: \(\(\sin \theta = \frac{1}{2}\)\) θ = 30°, 150°

Answer: θ = 0°, 30°, 150°, 180°, 360°
